title: How sequencing risk could crush your nest egg
text:
This chart from global actuarial firm Milliman shows the dangers of sequencing risk for new retirees and the dramatic effect of a market shock on savings longevity.

A 65-year-old retiree who experiences a 17 per cent loss within the first year of retirement, on a $500,000 portfolio, will run out of money at 85, assuming she achieves an average annual return of 4.2 per cent plus the inflation rate.

Another retiree with the same portfolio, who does not experience a market shock in the first year of retirement, would run out of money at 95 – a 10-year difference with a huge impact on their lifestyle and wellbeing.

Sequencing risk relates to the timing of withdrawals in retirement. Investors who have to draw down on capital during a bear market do so at depressed prices. As their capital shrinks, there are less funds available to benefit from an eventual sharemarket recovery.
